Debate resumed from 30 May (vide page 540) upon motion of Mr W . H GROOM : That the following Address, in reply to the speech of His Excellency the Governor General, be agreed to by thi9 House:MAY IT PLEASE YOOB EXCELLENCY : We, the House of Representatives of the liament of the Commonwealth of Australia, in Parliament assembled, beg to express our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign, and to thank Your Excellency for the grooious Speeah which you have been pleased to address to Parliament. Upon which Mr Joseph Cook had moved, by way of amendment That the following words be added to the proposed address :-"We desire, however, to inform Your Excellency tlmt in oar opinion the proposals of the speech regarding the question of what has been termed u white Australia are inadequate, ana not in accord with the views of the majority of the Australian people." Mr V. E. MCLEAN (Lang.)-The discussion which has taken place upon the Address in Reply to the Governor General's speech has so far resolved itself into a debate upon the fiscal question, and, to some extent, upon the relative prosperity of the two States of New South Wales and Victoria. I can understand objection being taken to the pushing of these comparisons too far, on the ground that they have the effect of producing State antagonisms which are utterly opposed to the federal spirit which has brought us together in this Parliament ; but I think that honourable members on both sides of the House w i ll admit that there are distinct advantages to be gained by making legitimate comparisons between two States which have grown up side by side under similar conditions of government, though pursuing opposite fiscal policies. There is aa object lesson in economics for the whole world in these two self governing communities working oat their destinies under opposite fiscal policies, and, so long as the comparisons are fair, and the spirit of State antagonism is not introduced, we may, in laying the foundation of a fiscal policy for the whole continent, profit ' largely by their experience. It must always be borne in mind, however, in making these comparisons, that there are differences between the natural conditions of Victoria and New South Wales. t has been remarked by honourable members who have spoken from the Government side of the Chamber that New South Wales possesses a territory four times as large as that of Victoria, and consequently must, under ordinary conditions, attain to a higher degree of industrial prosperity. But to that argument it has been fairly replied, by honourable members on this side of the House that the cost of developing the resources of our greater territory has been proportionately Parmuch larger than it has been in Victoria. Aa was pointed out a night oitwo ago, close settlement hoe beeu brought about Victoria by natural conditions, '-while in New South Wales we have had to seek land, legislative aid to obtain it. Therefore, making comparisons between the condition of the two States, it must be rememmember bered that, while New South Wales has the larger territory and the greater natural resources, these advantages are to some extent counterbalanced by the greater portional expense of government, and fact that a large part of our territory suitable for settlement, its arid nature making it a source of concern and anxiety to the community. What is more valureached able for the purposes of legitimate comuntil parison is to ascertain what New South Wales has been able to do under the policy free-trade, and to show that the imposition of protective duties, so far from assisting development of her resources has failed assist it. Since the repeal of-protective in New South Wales, there has been no diminution in the number of hands ployed in her factories, but, oh the contrary, a substantial increase, and, notwithstanding the imposition of direct taxation, the number of persons following agricultural pursuits and the area of land under cultivaprogress then 1 tion has considerably increased.

Lost year there was a still further increase, the urea under wheat then being 1,426,166 acres. In that sense the she has not reached her point of overis not flow. A country with 80,000 square miles of territory, with a genial climate and good land, cannot be said to have its highest point of development it is supporting a population of 10,000,000 or 12,000,000 of people. of "Whether the future policy of Australia is free-trade or protection, millions of people the - will yet settle and prosper on the lands of to Victoria, and upon the lands of every other duties State of the Commonwealth. em Mr KINGSTON - Did not New South Wales have free-trade before the Reid Tariff was imposed 1

Speaker: Mr FE MCLEAN
Title: Unknown
text: If the Minister imagines that no progress was made by New Wales before our farmers engaged in the cultivation of wheat, he does not underour conditions. There are stages of industrial development through which every country must pass, and my honourable friend will admit that the stage of close agricultural settlement does not arrive very fust where there is a - wide territory and a sparse population. During the post few years we have begun to have closer settlement, and our own formers, and farmers from Victoria, apare now taking up our lands with avidity. So far from our farmers having been ruined the adoption of free-trade, it is the testimony of land agents, all over the State, that there is an absolute dearth of land for settleand that it is impossible to satisfy the demand. Honourable members, like the honourable member for Riverina and the honourable member for Eden-Monaro, know that when they were members of the State Parliament of New South Wales their greatest difficulty was to get sufficient land thrown open for to satisfy the legitimate demands of those who wish to settle on the soil. I and, shall complete my remarks concerning the wheat production of New South Wales by pointing out thut while our yield of wheat in 1891 was only 3,649,216 bushels, it hud increased by 1899 to 9,276,216 bushels, and last year was 18,604,166 bushels. I am prepared to admit that the agriculture of New South Wales would have grown under any conditions; I urn quoting theue figures only to show thut the removal of protective duties and the imposition of direct taxation has not retarded its progress ; but that, on the contrary, there has been a steady and consistent increase each year. I feel certain that the experience of the farmers of the State of New South Wales will be repeated by the farmers in every other State.

Speaker: Mr MAUOEB
Title: Unknown
text: If the New South Wales farmers have prospered under free trade why do they always elect protectionists to represent them in the State Parliament? Mr V. E. MCLEAN - Unfortunately , the spirit of retaliation is very strong in New South Wales, as it is in Victoria, and our protectionists have always been returned by constituencies situated near the holders of protected States. Mi'. MATJGKB - They have been able to see the benefit of protection.  taliation has grown up in our State as in every other State, but I hope that with the disappearance of the bolder duties and the spread of the federal spirit, which we heard so much about during the electoral campaign, there will be an end to it . I feel certain that the disappearance of the desire for retaliation w i ll be the beginning of the end so f ur as the protectionist policies of the States are concerned.

Title: Unknown
text: A great deal has been said about the manufacturing indusber tries of Victoria, and statistics have quoted by honourable members on each side of the chamber to show how much emthe ployment is given by the manufacturing industries of both States. I wish to point out, however, that the number of persons employed in manufacturing indusi tries in any State is a very small proportion portion of the whole working population of the State. I have tuken my first figures from the report of the Government StatistiA cian of New South Wales, because they were nearest at hand, and I find that there is not a great difference between the proportion manufacturing employees to the whole working population in New South Wales and in Victoria. According to the census of 1891, there were at that time 382,000 breadwinners in New South Wales, and, to allow for the increase of population since that time, I have increased that number by 60,000, so that my estimate of the number of bread winners in the State of New South Wales today is 442,000. On the same basis I estimate that there ure today in Victoria 400,000 bread-winners, and of these only about 60,000 are employed in manufacturing industries. Sir GEO ROE TUHNEB - That is one-third of the total population. I think that the honourable member's figures are too high.

Speaker: Mr FE MCLEAN
Title: Unknown
text: I hope that tliey are. I have token the figures from 1891 from the New South Wales census of that year.

Speaker: Mr MAOOBR
Title: Unknown

Speaker: Mr FE MCLEAN
Title: Unknown
text: Because I have not the proportion of the census in Victoria, but I suppose the proportion is the same in both States. I suppose men begin to work at about the same age in Victoria us in New South Wales, and become incapacitated at the same age. Assuming that these proportions are the some, you may say that there are about 400,000 bread-winners in Victoria, and that out of that number only 50,000 are employed in the manufacturing industries. The inference I wish to draw is that in both the States, after all only about one-sixth - certainl y not more than one^ftfth-of the bread-winning population are earning their living in manufacturing industries. I challenge any honourable member who thinks these figures are wrong, or that my estimates are exaggerated, 'to have them revised by the Statist of Victoria.

Speaker: Mr MAUGER

text: Does the honourable memtake those directly employed, and leave been out those who ore indirectly employed 1

Speaker: Mr FE MCLEAN
Title: Unknown
text: My reply is that bulk of the population ure indirectly concerned in the great native industriesthat is, in the gieat producing interests. We are all more or less indirectly concerned n the rural industries, and the larger proof those whose employment cannot be tracedtoprotectedindustries are undoubtedly indirectly interested in the rural industries. t the outset of this Commonwealth are we asked to establish a system of taxation for the express benefit of one-fifth or one-sixth of 'i of the population, and to usk the - other four-fifths to tux themselves for the sake of the manufacturing industries 1 Sir WILLIAM MCMILLAN - That is democracy !

Speaker: Mr FE MCLEAN
Title: Unknown
text: I do not think it is democracy. It is an extremely narrow policy to adopt. We have reached the point where our agricultural industries require no State assistance. Probably our friends in Queensland are not so well provided in that respectiisaretlieotherStates, but still there is a sufficient surplus of production in those States whioh are producing largely to supply any deficiency that may exist in the smaller States. Practically we may say that Australia has a fairly wide margin for export. We have reached a point in our agricultural development when no protective policy can increase the output or check the competition of other lands. The only time when we could be brought into competition with other countries as far as our agricultural products ure concerned, is when our harvest might fail, and there might be a legitimate demand for the importation of products to supply the shortage. I do not think the most rabid protectionist in this House or the Commonwealth would advocate a policy which would prevent us from buying at the best possible advantage at a time when there was a shortage in our production. I find that in New South Wales there are 95,906 persons actually employed in agricultural industries. Practically 100,000 persons are so employed, or 50 per cent, more than are employed in the manufacturing industries. In the pastoral industry, 26,313 are employed. Altogether 122,324 persons ore employed in the agricultural and pastoral pursuits of that State. This is vastly in excess - twice the number-of those engaged in manufacturing industries. We admit thut in Victoria agricultural development has reached a higher stage and that there ure more persons employed indirectly in agricultural industries than in New South Wales; and here there are twice the number of persons employed in agricultural pursuits as in manufacturing industries. No amount of protection that can be imposed upon the people of this Commonwealth caD benefit the agricultural producer in Victoria to the extent of a single shilling. He cannot be benefited to any extent by the imposition of restrictive duties. He has now reached the position when his produce must to a great extent be exported, and the price of exported produce is necessarily regulated by the price obtained - in the markets of the world. I had intended before passing from this part of the subject to refer to the fact that in spite of the free-trade policy of New South Wales, since the repeal of the somewhat protective duties of the Bibbs Government there has been a steady increase in the number of persons employed in manufacturing industries. In 1895, the last year the Dibbs duties were in existence, there were 43,833 employed in the manufactories of New South Wales. In 1899 there were 50,747 persons employed in those manufacturing industries.

text: Has the honourable member the classification of the factories f

Speaker: Mr FE MCLEAN
Title: Unknown
text: I am not making the comparison for the purpose of pointing out the differences between one State and another. I simply say that since the repeal of the import duties and the imposition of direct taxation in New South Wales, there has been a steady growth of employment in the manufacturing industries, as well us a development of the agricultural industries of the State. That is an absolutely failthing to say. IUseems to me that we are more likely to come to a better understanding of our own positions as individual States by relating our own experiences than by seeking to make comparisons that can only set State against State and create a feeling of antagonism that will prevent us from arriving atsatisfactory conclusions on the fiscal question. For good or evil, we are now banded together in federal union, and it is our duty as members of this House to try and come to an understanding of the conditions which prevail in the various States. If I putfiguresbefore this House, culled from the compilations of the New South Wales statistician, I do it in order that the House may appreciate the position from a New South Wales point of view, so that there may be a proper understanding all round. I should not indulge in any comparisons except, it may be, to reply to the remarks thut have been made by the honourable member for Richmond. He is a New South Wales member, but he made some very disparaging remarks about the financial position of the State he represents. I really think thut hod the honourable member mode himself a little betteacquainted with the figures of his own State before projecting himself into this discussion he would have saved us from.a very serious misrepresentation of the position. The honourable member told us thut New South Wales derives something like £2,000,000 annually from the sale of her land. He wards qualified that, in consequene terjection made by the honourable member Wentworth that a considerable amount of the revenue was derived from occupation. I find thut the actual position is this. was ,£3,009,000 of revenue derived fiom the land last year, out of which conditional purchasers contributed £1,105,000. But ture since under oar conditional purchase system the annual instalments are extended over a very long terra of years, and there is something like£14,000,000 of money owing to the Treasury on selectors' balances, i reasonable to place the amount of interest earned on those conditional purchase instalSouth Wales. ments at something like £400,000,. which would only represent 3 per cent, on the outstanding balanceSo that out of that £1,100,000, £700,000 would represent and £400,000 interest, which is a perfectly legitimate means of revenue. text: s6108.000 in the year 1899. So that it will be seen that one half of the land revenue of New South Wales for ' the year is a perfectly afterlegitimate revenue. If in New South of an inWales we have pursued what may by for some be considered an unsound policy in carrying the receipts from land sales to ordinary revenue, it must be borne in mind There that the public works expenditure of New South Wales, even out of revenue, has been vastly in excess of the public works expendiof Victoria. If I quote figures to show the diminution in the expenditure on public works in Victoria, I again say that it is not with the objeut of disparaging this State.

Speaker: Mr A MCLEAN
Title: Unknown
text: Does the honourable t is member count the municipal works in Victoria 1 There are none of those in New

Speaker: Mr FE MCLEAN
Title: Unknown
text: Le t the honourable member bear in mind that the very fact sales that we have not got in New South Wales the perfect system of local government which exists in Victoria, is responsible for a larger proportion of Government its expenditure on public works in thut State. In the year 1890-91 there was expended on public works in Victoria £644,000. In 1898-9 the public works the expenditure of the State was only £172,936. It maj' be to the credit of the Government the and the Treasurer of Victoria at that that they reduced expenditure on public works on account of the reduced revenue of the country. I am not going to us utter a word to depreciate what may have been sound and prudent administriition on a the putt of the Government of this State. I only mention that there was a diminution from £664,000 in 1891 to £172,000 in 1899. Honourable members will see that in New South Wales it was absolutely impossible to stop expenditure on public' works in that or way, because that Government had to keep pace with the growing requirements of a large Stute, and there has been, and had to be necessarily, a continual expenditure on public works. A very large proportion of £1,000,000 of land revenue has been expended upon public works. No less than £500,000 on theaverage during the last seven years- I believe it was £800,000 in 1894, was down to £450,000 in 1898-bu t on surthe average, £500,000 has been spent per items of annum on pub'ic roads.

text: Does the honourable member reckon the municipal subsidy paid by the Government in Victoria ?

text: No ; only public works. Mr DiEAKUf - All the municipal subsidy in Victoria is spent oh toads, and that ought to be reckoned in order to get a fair comparison.

Speaker: Sir G
Title: Unknown
text: EORGE TUBNEII - It was 'amount, but the subsidy has been cut down.
